I have once again spent my entire Sunday in bed. Half sleeping/half reading, but none the less in bed. I actually made two calls today that really made those two people's day. It felt so good to hear my friend say "Its so glad to hear your voice, I've had a terrible day today". We are now on Day 17 of the countdown. I was looking into rental cars for when I get home and my friend was right it was so cheap for weekly rental. The days I put in they said it would be $116.00 for the whole week! That's excellent. I'm going to look further into that because it will be a blessing to have wheels knowing how much of a busy body I am. Of course I have things I should be doing but laying in bed after running around all week is so relaxing! Alas, duty and my hungry stomach call...

Tonight I had yet another wonderful Thankgiving-esque dinner. This time it was at Hazel and Terry's (which for some reason I always say Tazel and Harry...my brain just can't get it right). Hazel ended up doing most of the cooking. I didn' t know that or I would have tried to whip something else up. I thought more of the guys would bring stuff but of course, all they brought was beer. Our evening was supposed to begin around 4:30, but I was delayed because I was trying to hurry up and finish E. Lynn Harris' book "Any Way The Wind Blows" before I left home. It ended up taking longer than I thought and I missed Hazel's phone call to get down there soon because she was in a house full of men (including her husband of course) who were talking about football and all sorts of random things that she was not interested in. I hurried to finish the book as well as the pasta dish I'd prepared (which surprisingly got rave reviews) so I could go rescue her. Ya know, Hazel looks so much like my Aunt Connie its funny. Well she doesn't look like her all the time, its the facial expressions etc. that really get me. Hazel's 34 and really feels like a big sister to me. I've actually met a few people like that here. Its really good to have since my sister and I aren't very close. Hazel made corn on the cob, beans and rice, mashed potatoes (fresh, not boxed) and 3 pies: sweet potato, pumpkin, and apple. Those pies really took me back home. She baked marshmellows on top of the sweet potato pie and I was really looking around for somebody's mama so I could slap her! (sorority joke) Hazel's a really great cook and since she and Terry are totally vegetarian I always get really healthy meals when I'm at their place. Tonight, I had a sit down with a guy who I usually ignore because half of the words out of his mouth are ignorant. He seems like a nice enough guy but he is young (just turned 22) and immature. Look at me calling someone young at 22, but its not his age, its his mind. I generally just have small talk with him because he is cool, but nothing deep because I don't like feeling like I have to be the spokesperson for Black people or explain my life and how I am to him. He always asks dumb questions about ethnicity and stuff and I just get tired of explaining so sometimes...I just don't deal with it. In life, here are some people who don't understand things (no specific thing, just things in general) but they kind of go with the flow and try to get in where they fit in. They figure it out the best way they know how or they wait until a more appropriate time to approach the subject. Not this young cat! What gets me most is that people dismiss what he says with "That's just because he's young". I am a true believer in the fact that we make allowances for people to remain how they are. By constantly giving them the "she's/he's just like that" out...we hurt them as much as their ignorance bothers us. I refuse to do that but for so long and their has to come a time, when everyone should not have to change because of one person and that person should start learning how to be a chameleon based on their situation. So anyway (as I step down off my soapbox) we sat and talked tonight and a lot of what he said helped me to put together pieces of why he is the way he is. We are alike in a lot of ways but still very different. It was just good to see a side of him existed that didn't involve him trying to keep up with the dozens and be like "the boys". He gets caught up in trying to fit in with the other guys who seem to have an ongoing game of "Who's line is it anyway?" trying to be quickest to say something smart or witty. If he would just be a little more confident in himself then maybe he'd find out who "himself" really is. I think he's looking but he'll never find him while he's trying to be them . I started reading Sue's book, "The Unbearable Lightness of Being. And in an oxymoronic way, this book is anything BUT light. I said I was going to try to do some light bedtime reading but its actually quite heavy...but coming off the Potter Series and E. Lynn this is going to be an interesting ride. I read 4 books this week that contained a combined total of 1,460 pages. I have a feeling, that even if I give it my all I won't finish this one book (311pgs) this week. But I will do my best. Wow, 1,460! I didn't realize it was that many...I promise you if any of them would have been for a class in undergrad I probably wouldn't have read them just out of principle...I was really a terrible student...but life has its way of making you a great pupil doesn't it...I digress, as usual. Oyasuminasai! Ganbarimasu!

Its a done deal! I'm going to New Zealand March 23-April 3. There are 9 of us in total going. Dave (the planner), Hazel and her husband Terry, Kris (from Kofu), Jeremy (from Ueno), Charlotte (who is a former JET), Shalini (I don't really know her, is a kinda know of her thing) and this guy named Jason (who may be a friend of my Japanese teacher and from Greensboro, NC but I'm not sure if that's the same guy). Its good that I know a good part of the group that way it won't be too strange but I think it will be great! The schedule the planner has for us thus far is hype! We are going to do some backpacking, sight-seeing, sea-kayaking, horseback riding, shopping, and water skiing! And there are like 4 or 5 days that haven't been planned yet! He is from New Zealand so we'll be staying with his sister and parents part of the time. It sounds like so much fun! It is the late spring in New Zealand now so it will be summer by the time we get there. The list of stuff we are supposed to be doing is all stuff I've never done before so I know its going to be great. I'm so out of shape so I better start doing some exercise tapes in my living room or something cause I'll be beat down the whole two weeks we are there. I'm going to need to find a "backpack" like the hikers and stuff wear too. I hope they aren't too expensive. I was thinking about what a friend of mine about not wanting to come back after all this out and about that I've been doing. Traveling here and there. I think all its doing is getting me more motivated to be productive so I CAN travel and go skiing, snowboarding horse-back riding, sea-kayaking and all the other things that "Black People ain't supposed" to do. Dave got one of the last 3 tickets yesterday to add me to the group so that was a close call. Yokkata Ne!

Okay, let me give you the skinny on Okinawa. I was sooo happy to see Vanessa!!!! She looked so good and the kids are gorgeous. They have such and adorable family. So we spent a lot of time on base. We went to Camps Kinser and Foster which are both Marine and then to Camp Kadena which is the Air Force. We went to and bought stuff from the PX on both camps. I went to the base Beauty Shop to get my hair cut which was a relief not being able to do it myself. Friday night we went to this club that was on base and it was soooo much fun!! It was free to get in, coat check was free, and drinks were $2.25!!!! I'm talking mixed drinks, top shelf, you name it $2.25! I was shocked. I spent less than $10 including club and drinks and it was packed and the party was live. So believe you me, I was happy about that. The guys in the club that night were funny. They were dancing and not so much worried about us. We had a really good time. The weather there was so much warmer than it is here on what the military folks call "mainland". The only problem with that was when I finally got back here I could feel the sore throat and coughing coming. I didn't get a chance to get many pictures but it was nice. Definitely not somewhere I'd like to live either because the land is too flat and much too much wind but like many other places in Japan nice to visit,not as fun to live there. The second night we went to this place that was supposed to be "the best night spot" and it was terrible. Well Erica had a wonderful time and the music was good. I just felt bothered the entire night. I must have been going through some serious PMS because everything that anyone said to me pissed me off. I didn' t want anyone touching me or dancing too close or looking at me. I was being a really "female dog" and I couldn't help it.I tried to go in the corner and sit because I didn't want to make Erica leave and not have a good time because I wasn't feelin' it but people kept coming wherever I was to bother me! I mean, I know they didn't want anything other than a little harmless conversation and usually I indulge them, but that day was just not the day.

Today after paying some bills and taking about an hour at the post office to transfer money I felt the need to treat myself to a nice dinner. I went to one of my favorite places called Gusto. Its a very nice restaurant and its also pretty inexpensive which is my favorite part. I don't know what made me thing about it...maybe it was the lady I hit with the bathroom door as I was exiting. I pushed on the door like I normally would, only problem is there is a sink on the other side of that door and if anyone is using it they are in the direct line of fire for the door. I felt really bad about hitting her and she was like "Sure, nevermind" That use of English was not exactly appropriate for the moment especially the way she said it, but anyway...after that I looked up in the mirror and asked myself "Eboni WHAT are you doing in Japan?" Its a logical enough question although at the time only meant to be rhetorical. My eyes are extremely heavy right now and I've got to get to bed...although I'm way behind on my journaling. I'm going to try to get up early tomorrow to plan my lesson for the Elementary school. If I have time, I'll journal then. The question still looms over my head as I drift off to sleep, Why are you in Japan?

Talk about snowing! Yesterday when my JTE said "Do you know it will be snow tomorrow?" I said "REALLY" I had no idea what we were in for. I woke up this morning moving around slow as usual and looked out and almost couldn't find my car. The drive in to work wasn't that bad. The road hadn't been plowed but there weren't any accidents and folks were taking their time. We ended up having a short day. The plan was to leave after the lunch around 12:40. But...the lunch truck was stuck behind an accident on the highway. It ended up geting to the school about an hour late. By then one school bus had already arrived to take the students back home. None of the teachers could leave because the Principal hadn't gotten back from an early morning meeting to say whether or not the teachers could leave. The VPrincipal can say the students can leave but he can't let the teachers go early. It makes me no nevermind, b/c I leave at 4:30 regardless. I hope the roads aren't bad and you can believe I will be driving slow. As if the snow wasn't enough to rack my brain...I called Keysha and asked her to by my ticket for the night bus from Kofu to Haneda. When she called the bus was already full!!! There are no other trains or buses that leave from this way up to Haneda so I thought I was royally screwed and going to have to drive. Then my teacher found a train in Tokyo that starts at 5:30 in the morning and runs every 11-14 mins that goes to Haneda. The only thing is, there aren't any morning trains that will get me there ontime. So, I have to go up to Tokyo and spend the night there tonight and take the other train to the Haneda Airport in the morning. Luckily I'm a friendly person and made friends w/these two black girls I met at the Earth Wind and Fire concert back in November. Anyway, I called this girl Yolandis who is still living here (the other girl went back...she was only visiting) and asked her if I could stay w/her tonight with a great big ONEGAISHIMASU and she said sure, no problem! What a relief! So now I have to get home rush around to make sure I have all I need which really wont be much since I will only be gone for the weekend. I have to find her a good gift too because she was very kind to me for letting me stay with her tonight. God is really good, ain't he?

Gosh, I have been really not feeling my job today. Probably because I have hopes of being in Okinawa this weekend I want the next few days to just skip by. In one of my classes at Toyoshige today the Vice Prinicipal sat in on the class. It was okay but I kinda felt like he was judging my performance. The class he sat in on was cool they are smart kids and we usually have a lot of fun. Its hard to be a performer when you don't feel like it. I talked to RR today and told him how "blahhhhh" I was feeling. He teased me that being home a few weeks spoiled me. But its very true I must be spoiled or maybe its "Just one of them days" that a girl goes through. Who knows I just want to be in my bed under something reading a book....i mean under some COVERS...right right, that's what I mean.

I had such a wonderful day today! i was so worried about skiing for my frist time and for no reason. I went out there and of course I rolled around in the snow (not purposely) for about 2 hours and then finally was able to stop standing up. I was among the A group people who had only been once or twice before and still they were far far ahead of anywhere I'd ever been. The teachers were really patient with me and I have to say, my ski instructor was a CUTIE! Problem was, "He no speaku no engrish" Oh well, nice to learn from and a cutie...so I enjoyed the lessons. The ski resort was called Fujiten and at the top of the slopes you can see Mt. Fuji when the clouds moved away. It was a good day. The wind wasn't blowing and the sun was hidden behind clouds most of the day so my eyes didn't hurt much. I'm so lucky to be at the school I'm at because they really treat me like one of them. A lot of other ALTs aren't allowed to go on the school trip but mine invited me. I was very thankful. I'm extremely beat now too so I'm going to get some rest. Oya sumi!

Good Morning Diary-san! I started my day by reading more of my new favorite book called The Great Investment . It was written by TD Jakes. Its my first read of him, but I am really enjoying it and learning. Its truly a great book. It deals with balancing Finance, Family and Faith. I am in need of some spiritual guidance right now because I feel a serious calling on my life and can't seem to get a hold of what it is. This book has really helped me get things into focus though so I'm looking forward to a really blessed year. Conviction + Confession = Change.

After all that about how cold it is in my place, I failed to mention that I didn't have any more kerosene in any of the 3 heaters I had. So grudgingly I got dressed and went next door to the gas station to fill my container up. I'm glad I did though, because after the gas man filled it up, he invited me in for a cup of tea. It was cool, he doesn't speak English of course but we sat and drank tea and at cake from about 9am-10pm. He had customers every now and then but came in and filled my cup and another older man who lives in the village came in and chatted with us a while too. Of course I didn't understand all of what he said, but it was good to be and feel welcome among the people I live with. He told me that he was sad I wasn't staying around for more than a year and wanted to know why I wouldn't stay. I told him that I missed my family and Japan was too cold. He was like "Ahh, you'll get used to it!" He's funny. What started off as a "I hate this temperature!" day quickly got transformed. I love Japan! I can be moody and no one really knows or cares. Off to go skating...ttyl Diary-san.

If there is one thing I can't stand about Japan its the fact that it is cold inside the house. It keeps me from doing so many things. If its warm I can get up and be the morning person that I am. Clean up, listen to the radio, do my Saturday planning for my upcoming week...the works! But when its cold, I'm talking 10 degrees and below in the house who wants to be bothered with anything but laying in the bed! I have to be careful about my eating habits over these next two months because I know I will overeat and lack of exercise or anything else to do will really blow me up. Now that I think about it, I have to make special trips to eat so maybe it won't be bad cause I know i'm not going to get up and go out in the cold to over eat. I took this really cool personality test someone sent me as a forward. Its apparently one of those things that Dr. Phil gave to Oprah and now they are passing it around. Oprah scored 38..this is what it said about her. Others see you as sensible, cautious, careful & practical. They see you as clever, gifted, or talented, but modest. Not a person who makes friends too quickly or easily, but someone who's extremely loyal to friends you do make and who expect the same loyalty in return. Those who really get to know you realize it takes a lot to shake your trust in your friends, but equally that it takes you a long time to get over it if that trust is ever broken. I scored 43..Here are my results: Others see you as fresh, lively, charming, amusing, practical, and always interesting; someone who's constantly in the center of attention, but sufficiently well-balanced not to let it go to their head. They also see you as kind, considerate, and understanding; someone who'll always cheer them up and help them out. Pretty accurate I think.

I'm going to OKINAWA. I'm going to OKINAWA!!! I booked my flight today. Next Friday I'm going down to visit Anna and her family. I can't wait to see the kids in person. I've been trying to think of what to bring them. I am turning Japanese, you know omiyage is a custom of theirs. Anyway, we'll see. I just cant wait to get down there. The weather is only in the 60s there but that's better than the 30s and teens which I'm experiencing here. Since I've decided that I'm only going to stay for a year, i'm going to try to take one trip a month. Even if its a small trip. I found a great deal for this and Erica and I are going together so that's saving money too. I'm excited Diary-san. I can't wait to tell you all about my trip! No, i'm not going to be able to buy any new clothes, but I don't need them. I have plenty. As part of my new 2003 debt free plan the purchase of new clothes is a MAJOR No-No so I have to resist all the urges of my mind. I digress...Gonna finish doing my hair then I'm going to bed. Oyasumi.

Lemme tell you why I'm mad son! Aiight so today I come home and just flipping through channels stop of something that is in English. No idea what it is only that they are interviewing folks and I understand what they are talking about. It ends up being some kickboxing program that was fairly interesting. Next this video program called "WOWOW" comes on. It shows different US videos. The first was Guns & Roses. It was a cool song, something kinda mellow. Then they had an interview w/NAS. And then his video came on for "Made you Look". (here comes the part when I get mad!) Guess what came on next? KISS. Some headbangin' screamin' and hollerin' KISS. I have finally returned! After a 3 week, well needed totally enjoyable vacation. The US is the same my family is the same the food folks and fun are the same and I was just glad to be back for a while. My first few days I stayed in RDU area reunited a long overdue flame, had a job interview, took it back to the El and partied Black tie style in honor of the Christmas holiday. Then I went down to the country where my family lives and we had my brother's wedding. It was ghetto love all the way. Not in a derogatory but you know there is nothing like country ghetto two folks who love each other. I'll not go into the details of the wedding or the reception but I will say this... They seem to be very happy and I am happy for them. I went to Connecticut to visit fam there and picked up my niece and nephew who I haven't seen in YEARS and took them to see this new movie called Drumline. We had a good time. I really will try to keep better contact with them. They're beautiful kids and of course growing up so fast. Its funny when you are young it seems like you'll never get old and when your older it seems like youth is so fleeting...I know I'm getting to be a senior citizen when I'm contemplating the pace of youth! It is now 5:35AM and I have been awake since about 2AM. My body still thinks I'm in the US. Its a good thing we have a long holiday weekend so that I can work on my sleep schedule. I still haven't unpacked completely so I guess I'll work on that. I still don't have any water since the water froze in my pipes while I was gone. Well actually it froze in the water supply not in the actual pipe but none the less I have no water and no toilet in my apt. I brushed my teeth and washed my face with bottle water which is also cold because of the temp in the kitchen. My supervisor said they would come back around 9AM to work on it. We'll see how that works out. I might have to go to a friend's house this weekend if they don't fix it soon because I will not be running to the neighbors house to pee and shower all weekend.

War...what is it good for... This week, I'm on a war movie marathon. At Tsutaya its 180yen rental day for ladies on Monday so I get to get cheap movies. I rented, Pearl Harbor, Band of Brothers, Black Hawk Down, and Behind Enemy Lines. I watched Pearl Harbor last night and Black Hawk Down the night before. I wanted to understand more about the war phenomenon and these movies both have a true story behind them and although of course movie is not as good as books or primary sources it has still lead me to write everyone I knew who has served in the armed forces and tell them how much I love an appreciate them for what they do. Everyone is really quick to criticize war and members of the armed forces, but I guess I never really sat down to seriously think about the things they do and what their jobs actually are until I started to date G . Two of my uncles were in the armed forces. One in the army the other in the airforce but even then I didn't do a lot of thinking about it. G , his job and his co-workers were visable to me on a regular basis and it made me come to grips with a lot of stereo types that I had about these men because of TV or whatever. They were men and some still boys who had volunteered to defend their country. Although some may never see wartime or combat (which I hope my loved ones don't) they train every day for the worst while hoping for the best. The man in Pearl Harbor said, "Nothing is more passionate than the heart of a volunteer." To the men and women in my life and everywhere who have volunteered (and those who wish they hadn't sometimes) you are truly some of the best people I know. Thank you for watchin' my back. Holla BACK!!! I got ya back!

Bye Bye Geneva. Tonight I went out with Aki for the last time in Japan. Aki, Keysha, Chris J and I went to an onsen (hot spring spa) at this fruit park up near Yamanashi city which is really really nice. It was extremely cold tonight which is all the more better for going to the onsen. I'm not usually a big fan of the public bath thing like so many people seem to be but I've been having some dry skin problems and my Japanese teacher told me that the hot spring water is really good for my skin every now and then. It acutally felt really good. First you go into this room with a bunch of showers and you scrub really hard. Once you feel good and clean, you go outside to the pools of water. The first one we got in was really hot. It was so hot that I got a little light headed at first but when I started to get used to it, it felt a lot better. Just sitting around talking to Aki and Keysha was cool. When that pool got too hot, we went down to the warm pool. It had big rocks in it so you could lay on the rocks when if you get hot. I felt like I was in the movie "Mermaid" laying on the rocks with my feet in the water. I'm kinda sad Aki is leaving. I don't feel like I got a chance to really know her like I could have if she would be able to stay around longer. She's been here for a year studying Japanese and its finally time to go home. I think that she got a little sad during the second half of her stay here because she got engaged and of course wanted to be with her fiance. The wedding will be some time later this year I think. Too bad I won't be able to make it. Anyway Aki is cool peeps and she's my birthday sister (we were born on the same day) so as long as I remember my 23 birthday party I'll remember Aki. Bon Voyage. Safiri Salama. Sayonara.

You can't see what I can see... Yesterday at Shoji I had an extremely humbling experience. In the 4th grade class there is a girl who was doing an experiment about being blind. She had to wear a blindfold from 9am-12:30 just before lunch time. It just so happens that my class is the class just before lunch. Another student was assigned to be her care taker for the morning. Of course since I can't speak Japanese in class I rely highy on pictures and some small bits of English combined with body language to help get the message across to my kids. It seemed at first as if she was okay...but as the class progress I could see her face getting more and more sad. I asked the girl who was taking care of her if she was okay, she said she was. Things really got heavy when we started to play this interview game. The students drew pictures of their family. I taught family grammer and the question phrase "Who is this?" Well the students were playing the game and and I looked over at her and she was crying! The homeroom teacher (who stays in the class with me to help translate and in case I have behavior issues, which never happens) goes over to her and starts talking to her and telling her to write about how she is feeling at the moment. Then she really breaks out crying and he finally takes the mask off of her. Some of the children are watching but most are so engulfed in the game that they pay her no mind. It was hard for me seeing her so bothered with her face buried in her arm quietly weeping. All the while I had to act like she wasn't crying and tend to the other students. Finally class ended and I got a chance to ask her teacher how she was feeling. He said the whole time she was writing, "I can't do anything on my own. I feel helpless. Isn't it time to take this off yet? When will lunch time come? I really don't like this at all." I'd something like that on tv, but never in real life. I wonder what the purpose of the whole experiment was? I couldn't really understand the definition they gave me in Japanese of course. It was an eye opening experience. I never see Japanese people show emotion the way I feel we do in the states. maybe they just don't do it around me but for some reason her crying really effected me. That's one of the main reasons I need to learn Japanese. There are so many things that are going on around me that I have no idea about. It just makes me want to study even harder, ya know?

Senseless Murders i had to share the comments of a friend of mine. she totally expressed my feelings completely... "yo...if you get a sec, do a news search (google) for chicago and chatham murders. I love my city by what's really going on? I heard around New Years that a family was killed (father, daughter, girl's baby and the father) on the southside. They even killed the dog. But what I didn't know was that this manhunt they were on, the dude that they were calling armed and dangerous, the most deadliest man in the history of the city, was an 18 year old! I couldn't believe this! The first groups of murders went unsolved. The boy lived next door to the people. Then earlier this month, he kills his father. Next he kills another 18 year old on the North side, injures her fiance' and then finally kills himself after a stand off at this hotel near my Granny's crib. When they found the boy he was dressed in a bullet proof vest and his pockets were filled with bullets. Eboni, he was killing these people with an Uzi! This shit is crazy! Seriously, what is wrong with people nowadays? I feel like a movie character saying this but people have no respect for life. There was another story on the CHicago Sun-Times site about another teenager who killed his grandmother and two kids! I'm not saying that Chicago, or any other place for that matter, hasn't had it's share of crime and violence but when have you ever heard so many stories of this magnitude at the same time? Seems like things are just getting really bad. Sorry for my "in-depth" email but I just hate to hear things like this. Especially when it involves black people. This is some shit that white folks used to do; get angry and go on a shooting spree. I guess I should have learned my lesson after the sniper rampage to never repeat that phrase, "Black folks don't do that." As of lately, it seems that each time I say it, I prove myself wrong."

It felt so good to be a lazy butt today! I washed 3 loads of clothes, cleaned the bathroom and laundry room, took out the garbage, packaged up my newspapers for burning, and took down my Christmas tree. Yes, just taking it down mid-feb. Its been a long cold winter and I haven't been up for much cleaning or adjusting stuff. I just left it there since Thanksgiving. It wasn't bothering me any!!! It was pretty nice today but still quite cold up in the boonies where I live. One thing I can say, IF (and that's a huge IF) anyone comes out here to visit me, they will get a taste of what the real heart of Japan has to offer. Not Tokyo or any of the big cities, but traditional rural Japanese life. No trains, no convience stores, just a gas station, a tennis court, an onsen, and a Town Hall. That's about it for us! We are situated between two mountains and this time of year only get a good 5 hours of direct sunlight. I have to make sure my clothes get out there as soon as the sun hits them and don't worry about them drying after 3 cause the sun is gone and it becomes cold again. The joys of Mt. living huh? After doing more than my fare share of Saturday work I decided I'd just watch some TV and eat junk food tonight. So, I went into Kofu rented "American Beauty" and "What lies beneath". I stopped off at a store to get more snacks than I really wanted or needed and huge bottle of orange Fanta. Made one more stop at McDonald's (can't eat all junk food right? I'm kidding of course. ) and came on in to start my Tsutaya Night. Tsutaya is the name of my movie rental place. Doesn't have quite the same ring as, "Make it a Blockbuster night!" but we do aiight with what we got. As I lift my bottle of Fanta (2L,and no I'm not getting a cup, I live alone, have no visitors, and plan on finishing it tonight) and pop open my can of Sour Cream Pringles...Here's to being a single beautiful Black woman and lovin' every moment of it! KAMPAIIIIII

Last night was so much fun!!! I started out kinda bumbed because I wanted to go to Tokyo for the Peace Rally on Saturday but found out after I left school that I don't get paid until Monday. Finances are usually slim a day or two before my expected pay day so I realized I couldn't afford to go. I had still been invited to this Chocolate themed Valentine's Day that I so inappropriately named "Valentine's Day Gone Wrong Party". And it was only when I got there that I realized how wrong I was. Sue had invited a bunch of people up to her place, actually not a bunch just 8 of us (and Wendy's dog Uribo) and I was the first to arrive. I walked up to the apartment and was greeted by the smell of citrus candles. This is also Sue's way of signaling her neighbors that she is having company. I walk in and she had little colorful gel candles lining the walk way to the living room. There were candles everywhere you look and everything smelled great! Shortly after I arrived the rest of the crew came in with bags and bags of chocolate flavored everything you can imagine and beer! I had two different types of mexican mole, which is a dish that is made with chocolate or chocolate powder. Rice and homemade tortillas were made to complement the mole. We had chocolate pizza, home made chocolate hearts, chocolate bubbles (yes, complete with bubble wand), and even chocolate cake that was made in the rice cooker! Someone also brought egg salad and avocado salad sandwiches that were cut out in the shap of hearts!! The food was really great and the company was even better. We talking about so many things, had a lot of great laughs, and even had a moment of mediation for peace and solidarity. We listened to old Whitney Houston songs, drank beer, played this card game called "spoons" which is one of my new favorites and really just enjoyed each other's company. What better way to spend Valentine's Day? Just before everyone crashed and we were playing our last round of our version of "Name that tune" I got my special Valentine's call from home that of course made my night that much more complete. Its amazing to me how a 5 minute conversation can put a great close on what had already been an amazing evening. Then the night came to a complete wind down and everyone decided we'd all drank too much to go home so we had a big slumber party. Quote of the evening: "What does love smell like?" Reply: "The wet spot"

I'm feeling empelled to write but I don't really have my ideas together about what it is I actually want to write. I just read one of Nikki Giovanni's poems "How do you write a poem?". I think it speaks volumes...I'll enter it after my post is done. Its Vday for us here and my friend is having a Vday get together tonight. The only requirements is that you bring a non-traditional chocolate object. She said it could be creative or not, just whatever you are feeling at the time. She told me she thinks I have some missed placed aggression because i want to bring a bashed up chocolate heart. I just feel like tearing something up. I'm not even having a bad day! You know one thing that pisses me off more than anything...okay not more than anything because we know a lot of stuff pisses me off...well one thing that has pissed me off is a letter I just recieved. I wrote this person...HANDWROTE--not typed a letter in early January. A four page letter like Aaliyah, Diary-san! And what did a get back? Some incoherant 1/2 page response which wasted the entired 37cent they paid for the stamp (didn't even bother to send it airmail). Now, you make think I'm petty when I tell you that the letter was recieved from a 13 year old family member but you know what, I don't give a &$@#. At 13 you are old enough to think clearly and write accordly. You are able to answer questions asked of you and write questions of your own other than that typical "how's japan?" "how's school?" mess I get from everyone including perfect strangers I meet. It upsets me when I take time to let someone know how I feel, give good feedback and say lots of positive things and I get something shitty like this back. I really want to write now and say some ugly stuff, but she's a kid. And not all kids realize the importance of proper and thoughtful correspondance. I'm not giving up on her though. I'm going to continue to write her and expect better letters in return. I'm hoping that she'll save them and I CERTAINLY intend to save the ones she sends me. WHEW! It feels so good sometimes just to get stuff off your chest ya know?

Peppermint Ball I has such a good time last night! A fellow JET participant friend of mine told me about the Tokyo Alumi Chapter and that they were having a formal event this weekend. A friend of mine had told me that the chapter was inactive so I never really bothered to get in touch with them. Well when the friend told me about it I decided to find out a little more for myself. I emailed the chapter president and she told me a few things and they were excited about meeting me and were so happy that I was here. When I got there I was so happy! It was so good to be around the sorors and feel at home again. Most of the sorors in the chapter are much older than me and are all in some way affiliated with the military someway. Most are teachers, some are actually in the military and the remainder are military wives. There was a banquet and some door prizes were giving away (which were all really nice ceramic dishes/vases for the home. I was for once hoping that I didn't win because I sure wouldn't want to lug that thing all around the train stations going home. They called all sorors to the floor and we sang "The Sweetheart Song" and as always it made me have goosebumps. The sorors could really sing too. The song sounded really good. I met two of the youngest sorors named Shai and Risha. They are both at the Air Force base and told me to come back down soon and spend the weekend. I told them I wanted to get my hair braided before I go to New Zealand so they said they'd find someone who could do that for me. The crowd was old and the music that was played all night was too, but that didn't stop me from having a wonderful time at all. I've got an adopted Mom now, this soror named Ms. Jackie. She took care of us for real and is going to send me a care package later on with some US goodies and Girl Scout Cookies. I wanted some thin mints but the girls we saw were all out!! The can never go wrong with Thin Mints. And as much chocolate as I've been eating lately I'd sit down and be done with the box in a night. I'm excited about getting the cookies though. Erica went with me and the interested girl. It was strange because some of the sorors were acting like Erica was interested too and not being quite as friendly to her as they were with me. She of course was like "F- em" (inside joke). Its funny, I was trying to explain to her why they were being that way but its hard to explain. I mean I totally understood it with the chapter being on the edge of membership intake and having women swarming around you who want to make new friends just for the sake of initiation possibilites, but that doesn't make it easy to explain to someone who hasn o interest in doing anything with Tokyo Alumni other than chillin' and supporting the worthwhile community activities they take part in. Today's weather was by far the most beautiful day of 2003 thus far. It was about 62 as a high and the sun was just gorgeous! I sat and missed two trains at the station in Machida on my way home from Camp Zama (where the ball was) just so I could sit outside reading and enjoying the sunshine on my face. Oh, I feel the bug of spring fever beginning to tickle my nose. My decision to stay in Japan will be final as of tomorrow morning and I hope the completion of this year proves as rewarding as the first part. Some will be happy that I'm staying others will not be so happy. But this is about me. I said that when I first left home. No kids, no boyfriend, no ring and no reason at this moment to return back home. God and I worked this one out. He provided a new sources of family and support in showing me the way to my sorors and I've just been recieving confirmations all week that this is the right thing for me to do. So I will turn in my contract tomorrow with no looking back and set forth in my obligations to the Kamiku BOE for another year. Wish me luck..and keep up the prayers.

Welcome to Black History Month I am dead sleepy but I have got get this in tonight. I went to pick up some English conversation listening CDs from Keysha for my Private students that I'll teach tomorrow. Well I'm sitting near her job at the train station waiting for her to come out when I hear some Japanese woman screaming into megaphones that are attached to the top of a small station wagon. It is the height of election season here and the way people campain is by driving around in cars and screaming something out at the people who are in earshot. Well the car eventually stop circling around the station and parked where else but right next to me. So I'm still sitting listening to my CD and playing with the email function on my cell phone. So all the passengers get out of this car including the candidate that all the hullabaloo is about. They walk around for about 5 minutes and pass out flyers and he gets on the megaphone and makes his speech. I am watching closely as this is HILARIOUS to me. I've never seen campaigning quite like it but it is of course "The Japanese Way" so like everything else I laugh and observe. Well when he is done, he comes back to the car to get in and has to walk past my window. When he does, he pauses at my window and asks me to roll it down. Then he says in perfect English, "Did you understand what I just said?" I shook my head "no" and he laughed and walked on. Then I asked him if I could take his picture. He says sure and stands up against the campaign car which has a huge plaquard on top w/his name or something up there. He gives me the cheesy "thumbs up" sign and I take the picture. Then he gestures for me to take a picture w/him and one of his campaign workers takes the photo of us. I say thanks and go to get back in my car when he stops me and gives me his campaign card and his business card w/his mailing address. Then he said "Please send me photo." I say, sure no problem and they start to leave. As he is backing out he looks back over at me and shouts "WE SHALL OVERCOME, WE SHALL OVERCOME!" I am so startled that I look at him and burst out in uncontrollable laughter. He is doing the Richard Nixon two hand wave and smile and drives off. This country provides me w/a new experience every day. Today, on the first day of Black History month I get a reminder, from a Japanese politician, of the reason why the month exists in the first place. Its about educating people and teaching about the importance, relevance, and context of Black History. The politician was right, We Shall Overcome...someday. I guess I just wish he knew implications that come with using that English phrase. Apparently he doesn't.

In today's post I take a moment to pause and reflect on the short time that I knew a wonderful person. When I went down to Camp Zama for the Delta Peppermint Ball about a month ago I met some wonderful sorors including one woman named Jacqueline Williams. We affectionately referred to her as Ms. Jackie. Ms Jackie was probably one of the oldest women in the chapter but just as lively and fun as the younger sorors. She made jokes with us and about us! We (Erica, Ameenah, Ms. Jackie and I) sat and watched Apollo after the Ball that night and overall had a good time. Tank (the singer) was on that night and we laughed as she looked at him and told us how FIONE he was and that he had a nice body! She reminded me so much of my aunts and older relatives with the old skool flava and modern slang. Erica and I had already invited ourselves up to celebrate Mother's Day with her. We were going to cook for her and everything. . .I am talking in the past tense because Ms. Jackie died in her sleep last night. She was in a hotel room on Camp Zama's base with one of her chapter sorors. They were spending the night there because there was a Delta Academy Cotillion last night that she was MCing. The Delta Academy girls were putting it on and had worked really hard and raised money for it. I didn't go because I wanted to save my money for NZ trip at the end of this week and now I'm sad in a way that I wasn't able to be around Ms. Jackie in her last few hours. Its so funny how life changes on us so quickly. She had just emailed me Friday telling me that she was going to get my girl scout cookies off to me that she had bought. She told me she had just been a little busy but was going to get aroundtuit soon. She said "Hold your horses lil sistah!" Boy I'm going to miss that lady. My prayer for Ms. Jackie: Lord you have helped me in many ways in the last nine months. One of the greatest gifts you have bestowed upon me is the opportunity to meet many different types of people and some of them have been people I'll never forget. About a month ago you brought a cheery woman in a bright red suit with a cream dress blouse who I knew upon seeing her was a Delta. She approached our table in the food court area of the PX who came in talking about wanting a "chicken and a biscuit". It was my pleasure to get it for her and anything else she needed cause she looked like she had already had quite along day. Once we checked into our hotel that night I even drove her car to the hall where the Ball was held because she wanted us to have her car so we could have a ride over there and she had to be there before us. Lord, there was a smile on her face everytime we saw her! I saw the beauty that only you can instill in someone's life radiating all over Ms. Jackie's person. I am saddened by her passing but I know that your arm swept her up where she belongs. It was her time to go and only you knew that and your reasons for bringing her home. Be with her family and give them strength to realize that we all belong to you and that no one is on earth any shorter or longer than you plan for them to be. Bless the lives that Ms. Jackie touched with her kind heart and warm smile. Give us comfort as we are reminded that you are the ruler of all and determine the length of our lives not we ourselves. Thank you again Lord for allowing me to even know Ms. Jackie for the brief time that I did and may we who love, cared, and were touched by her always think of Ms. Jacqueline Williams with a smile on our faces. In your name Lord, I pray all these things and I give you honor and praise for who you are, who you have been to me and mine, and will continue to be as long as my days on this earth are intended to be. Amen.

What a wonderful place Kyoto is! Hazel and I took the bus down there Thursday night. It was a really comfortable bus. They had slippers to put on and a blanket to cover you up while you slept. The bus left Kofu at 10ish and got to Kyoto around 6am ish Friday morning. It was too early to even get a cup of coffee or a piece of fruit so we just went to the bathroom washed up and walked around the train/bus station checkin' it out. It was a pretty big station too and around 7 we finally were able to go to the information desk, get a map and try to find our way around and map out our plan for the day. We bought these 2 day bus/subway passes for about 2,000 yen which turned out to be really good investments because the buses go all over the city and come quite often. Day one we went to Ginkaku-ji (the silver temple), Eikan-do, and Nanzen-ji. We went to lunch at this wonderful little restaurant that was recommended to us by Lonely Planet Japan called Hinode. They saw our Lonely Planet book on the table and got excited. The owner was so nice! We asked him for directions on how to get to our hostel and he didn't know so he took our book and called the place to get the directions. Then he proceeded to draw us out a map from the restaurant to the place which he said would take about 20mins walking. After we left the restaurant and had probably walked for about 5-7 mins, the owner pulls up next to us and offers to drive us to the hostel!!! It was such a nice thing to do. Just when some Japanese folks piss ya off, you find folks like the man from Hinode (who's name we never even got) who do such benevolent things. The place we stayed was kinda shaky. It was a dorming house for foreigners. Some long stay as well as short stay. It was fine because we only had to stay there one night but longer would have been a problem. It was an 8 mat tatami room with a small balcony and a kitchenette, if you can call it that. I refer to it as the dungeon and am glad we only had to stay there one night!!! After we found the place we unloaded a few souveniors we bought and set back out to the rainy streets of Eastern Kyoto. We headed back up towards Maruyama Park where there was supposed to be a festival of lights and some stage performances. We were most excited about seeing the Geisha women dance. Its funny because I never knew how important Geisha were to Japanese society. They are actually like the highest level of feminity that a women can be. They are very well trained in Japanese art of tea ceremony, dance, ikebana (flower arranging) and many others. The women who train to be Geisha area called Maiko. I think I was told some begin as Maiko at the young age of 15! Anyway it was really nice and so cool to actually get to see them dance and sing. The kimono they wore were beautiful!! And their make up was flawless. After that we walked around and took pictures of the scenery and the way they had lit everything up. It was a great atmosphere. Nice date spot too! Then we left to go find a onsen type bath. The only thing is the water wasn't hot spring mineral water. It was just regular water. We did that and then set out to find dinner and go back to our hotel. The dinner thing was hard because it was late when we got done bathing. It was about 10ish when we got back down to Gion, which is the hot spot night area. The other thing is Hazel is a vegetarian which in Japan is hard in the first place and especially if you are just eating out and don't really know where to go. We finally found this one Asian restaurant that I throughly enjoyed but Hazel ended up not being able to eat much. She's very accomodating so it wasn't bad and she would never complain but we had to eat soon because I was turning into the mean hungry E which isn't a pleasant person so she didn't mind eating there. What a whirlwind first day and the second proved to be just as busy. We got up pretty early and planned out our next day turned in the keys and set off into Kyoto. Today we planned to hit a few spots we'd missed the day before and a bunch of new stuff. We took a bus down to the Station so we could put our heavy stuff in a locker and set out for the temples. We grabbed a bite to eat at the station which ended up being much more suitable for Hazel. Then we took the subway up to Nijo Castle. This was probably my favorite next to the Park. It was so tight!! It was the home of the famous shogun Tokugawa. Inside the castle there are "nightengale floors". This means that whenever walk the floor boards have a distinct squeaking sound. The floors were contructed for that purpose that wherever you walked squeaks to protect him from intruders and so he always knew when someone was coming. Since the builiding is so old they don't allow photos to be taken inside but I'm trying to hold on to the mental images as much as I can. We saw the room where he held his cabinet meetings and they had these doors that were roped with this bright orange cord. Wherever this cord was on a door there was a bodyguard behind it to protect the shogun in an emergency. I think there were some peep holes in the door too, but we couldn't get up close enough to see it. This castle is surrounded by a moat which is the first time I've actually seen something like that NOT on TV. There were beautiful Japanese style gardens that I did get a few pictures of. It was just really nice and peaceful. I enjoyed it throughly. Next we went to a dragon processional at Kiyomizu Shrine. No one told us about the 15 min uphill climb to the temple, but the walk and fatigue was WELL worth it. We walked around once we got to the top and I spotted a group of Japanese folks standing around so naturally we went up there. I told Hazel that anytime you see Japanese folks in a group just waiting...you go then! Because it is usually something worth waiting for. Shortly there after, piles of people just seemed to come out of NO WHERE pushing and shoving to get to the front. We held down the front line though and Hazel got some really good movies with her digital camera. Mine takes the movies but there isn't any sound so its no good to take movies of that kind of thing. It was awesome though. First 8 buglers came down dressed in this heavy green and orange gear. The buglers were playing conk shells (not sure about the spelling) but when you blow in them an amazing sound some out. Next the soliders came down, then the priestesses and the high priest and finally the dragon! It was carried by about 10 -12 men and they really moved it like it was a dragon body! I was so impressed. They came down and the priestesses put something over the crowd out of their bowls using a wand of some sort and then the whole processional went down that hill we'd just come up! It was sooo cool! After they left some of the people standing around followed them down. We took another hill cause we didn't want to be in the traffic. We came across this shop where this 80 year old woman had made these gorgeous little paper Japanese women folded into bookmarks. They were only like $3 a piece so we both bought a few. After that we went to this place called Sanjusan gendo. It was a temple that had 33 something or others but I'm not sure what. It also had 1000 budda statues with over 10,000 arms. They say that all the faces of these statues are different and one looks like you. You just have to figure out which one it is. We got there when it was almost closig time so we didn't get to see much. We left there and went back up to the park and saw a wonderful taiko drum performance. After that we went to another bathhouse. This one was much better than the first but harder to find. Both of us were craving to go back to Hinode where we had lunch the first day but couldn't justify going all the way back up there until that is we found a subway near the bathhouse! So we took a subway and then a short bus to the place and guess what!!! They were closed! I couldn't believe it. We had wasted so much time getting there too that we didn't have time to get to a nice restaurant before time to catch the bus home. So, we just caught a cab back down to the station picked up our packages from the lockers, went to McDonalds for some fries and an apple pie and then to this quick beef bowl shop. I think Hazel got rice and a tofu soup. We rushed back across the street in time to catch the night bus back home to Kofu Admist the heat and slight snoring I had a pretty enjoyable and restful ride home and a great weekend. I'm looking forward to New Zealand even more now because I know that Hazel and I can and enjoy traveling together so that's a relief. I'm pretty much down for whatever and so is she so it wasn't stressful at all. It was cool. I'm glad we got a chance to go together!!!
